name: Aleph
immunity: charmed, exhaustion, frightened, paralyzed, petrified, poisoned
languages: the languages of its creator, usually Dwarvish

effect.text: The aleph is immune to any spell or effect that would alter its form.

The aleph regains all of its hit points at the start of its turn. If the aleph becomes wet, this trait doesn't function at the start of the aleph's next turn. If wet, the aleph dries out at the end of its next turn. The aleph dies only if it starts its turn with 0 hit points while wet. An aleph in a body of water becomes paralyzed, despite its immunity.

A grafted host gains 10 temporary hit points at the start of the aleph's turn as the aleph forms an outer crust of magma for protection. A creature that damages the host while the temporary hit points remain takes 3 (
The aleph's innate spellcasting ability is Wisdom (spell save
+ the Proficiency modifier of its host). It can innately cast the following spells, requiring no components:

The aleph melds into the body of a golem or other construct within 5 feet. While in its host body, the aleph has total cover against attacks and other effects from outside. If a grafted host is targeted by dispel magic or an area of antimagic, the aleph must succeed a Constitution saving throw against the caster's spell save DC or be forcibly removed and placed in an empty space within 5 feet. An aleph is similarly removed if its host dies.

While grafted, a host gains the Intelligence, Wisdom, and Charisma scores of the aleph if they are higher than the host's, as well as its blindsight and languages. The aleph has total control over the host, which loses its own initiative and is instead controlled on the aleph's turn.
The aleph uses the multiattack of its host, if any. Otherwise, the aleph uses one of its host's attacks. Instead of one of the attacks, the aleph can cast a spell.

legendary.info: The aleph can take 2 legendary actions, choosing from the options below. Only one legendary action can be used at a time and only at the end of another creature's turn. The aleph regains spent legendary actions at the start of its turn.

effect.text: The aleph forces its host to move up to its speed.

info.desc: The long-forgotten constructs of Gemfathom continue to execute their designated tasks endlessly. Danger persists within the mines, but no invention inspires as much fear in would-be adventurers as the Lightning Golem. Built to defend the tunnels from the threat of deep dwelling evils, the golems were soldiers, artillery, and transit all in one. The howdah on their back was meant as a means of escape and protection for fleeing dwarves. Their powerful arms would shock any monster into submission, while the beam that shot from their chest could melt through stone. Now abandoned, the golems have difficulty pinpointing friend from foe due to a lack of circuitry maintanence. Some creatures the golem was built to destroy have now inhabited the fortress carried on their back, turning them back into nigh-unstoppable war machines.

info.desc: Pomonids don't reproduce, nor do they have discernible gender. They do their best to live a healthy and good life, hoping to see a peaceful end of their days. When passing, other pominids will bury their bodies within lush groves. From the deceased grows a pominid tree, which after time bears fruit. The fruit matures into baby pominids, which fall to the ground by giving birth. Pominids believe that the number of pominids a pominid tree produces in their afterlife is determined by how many strangers the pominid helped during its lifetime. A pominid only lives an average of 50 years, and thus their desire to help others occasionally manifests as an overwhelming generosity.

effect.text: The wing devil has three layers of plumage that make it difficult to target. Each time a creature targets the wing devil while it has plumage remaining, roll a d20 to determine whether the attack could instead target its plumage. If it has three layers, it must roll a 6 or higher to change the attack's target to its plumage. With two layers, it must roll an 8 or higher. With one layer, it must roll an 11 or higher. The plumage has the same AC as the wing devil. If an attack hits the plumage, the wing devil takes no damage but the layer is destroyed. A layer of plumage can be destroyed only by an attack that hits it. It ignores all other damage and effects.
A wing devil's three layers plumage regrow after a short or long rest.
Magical darkness doesn't impede the devil's darkvision.

The yen can spend a short rest eating a limb or body part of a humanoid creature. During its next long rest, the yen forms a cocoon. When it emerges, the yen's corresponding body part is replaced with an exact replica of the body part it had eaten.

The yen can also spend a short rest eating the brain of a spellcaster. After its next long rest, it learns a spell the spellcaster had prepared at their moment of death. The spell must be of a level for which it has spell slots, and it is always considered a prepared spell for the yen.
To represent a yen that has already feasted on spellcasters, add up to three spells of differing levels to its list of prepared spells. They can be from any class.
The yen usually has two arms. Whenever the yen takes 20 or more damage in a single turn, one of its arms falls into the closest empty space and becomes a

At the beginning of its turn, it grows two arms for each of its arms that it lost since its last turn, unless it has taken necrotic damage since its last turn. The yen regains 10 hit points for each arm regrown in this way.

The limbs that regenerate from this trait are from previous victims of the yen's ingestion trait. When the yen is depleted of limbs from previous victims, the yen's true form is revealed, and this trait ceases to function.
